Title: The 0/1 Knapsack Problem - Dynamic Programming Method
Comment:
You can do it from the right instead.  And when you do it from the right, you can actually just use the same row and overwrite it, instead of having a different row for every time you add a new item.

Then, for the keep array, instead of storing 1 or 0, you'll store the weight of the item that was last used to reach there.  So in the example he gives, the keep array would look like this after he finished: 1 1 3 3 1
And it would be "the last item we used had weight X" and then you backtrack.

Title: The 0/1 Knapsack Problem - Dynamic Programming Method
Comment:
I guess we should take a step back.  This idea works for all numbers of additional constraints in that it reduces the dimension you need by 1.  So for the original problem with only 1 constraint, you'll only need a 1 dimensional array. If you can understand that, then applying that idea to more constraints is relatively straightforward.

It all depends on how you store the keep array, and how you iterate through the regular array.  See how in the video, he iterates from the left?  You can d

Title: The 0/1 Knapsack Problem - Dynamic Programming Method
Comment: OK, you don't need to store the entire V matrix to solve the problem.  But I can't see how you can not store the entire keep matrix and solve the problem.  You need the keep matrix to back track at the end.

Title: The 0/1 Knapsack Problem - Dynamic Programming Method
Comment: Couldn't fit over 500 characters, so I responded to my own comment with another bit that has the 2D way.  500 characters isn't enough to explain DP well, lol

Title: The 0/1 Knapsack Problem - Dynamic Programming Method
Comment: ... and the 2D way?

Title: The 0/1 Knapsack Problem - Dynamic Programming Method
Comment:
Except instead of looking at the previous row, you'd look at the whole previous 2D array.  And instead of only subtracting the 'weight' of the current object, you subtract both the 'mass' and the 'volume' and then look back that cell in the previous 2D array.

The keep array would be done the same way, I suppose.

In order to do this with only a 2D array used for the keep, instead of storing '1' or '0' to indicating using the item, you would store the mass and volume of the last item used.

Title: The 0/1 Knapsack Problem - Dynamic Programming Method
Comment:
No, so I'll go into a bit more detail how to do it with a 2-D array.

Suppose we have two limiting constrints, M mass and V volume.  Our objects that we want to place into our bag have distinct value c, mass m and volume v.  We want to select the best set of items to maximize our value without using too much mass or volume.

The 3D way is to have, for each of our N objects, a 2-D array of M+1 x V+1 dimension.

Then you would apply the same process as demonstrated in this video.

Title: The 0/1 Knapsack Problem - Dynamic Programming Method
Comment: I'm thinking the problem with two constraints can be solved with two three dimensional arrays, but I'm not sure about the details.

Title: The 0/1 Knapsack Problem - Dynamic Programming Method
Comment: Yeah, but then the complexity will go to O(nmv) runtime and O(nmv) space.  The problem is the O(nmv) space because that will get to be pretty large even if both m and v are relatively small.  You can improve it to O(mv) space, but it still is pretty bad.  Not impossible though!

Title: Matrix Chain Multiplication - Dynamic Programming
Comment: Great video and great explanation. But it's only half of the solution. There are TWO matrices to be filled simultaneously throughout this (or any other dynamic programming) algorithm. The first matrix m[ , ] for the optimal values - which is the one you filled, and the second matrix s[ , ] for storing  the optimal values of k for each corresponding optimal value computed (those k values you magically "recalled" at the end). Without constructing the second matrix s[ , ] for storing the optimum choices for k at each m[i,j], there's no way for a computer to re-construct the optimal parenthesization from the table m[ , ].

Title: Matrix Chain Multiplication - Dynamic Programming
Comment:
Hello. First off, a great set of videos. Thank you.

Here in this problem, the cost of multiplication,
M[i,j] = M[i,k] + M[k+1,j] + (p.values)

Here what are the p-values, and how does one know when/how/if-at-all to add it.

Title: RL Course by David Silver - Lecture 3: Planning by Dynamic Programming
Comment:
-- At 28:00 I can see an *error* on the k = 3 left grid. 
For (2 row 3 column cell) it should be arrows in all directions (from -3.0 to all -2.9).
And or course the same is for the (3 row 3 column cell).
So "optimal policy" is not yet here for k=3

-- Also at 25:00 on the right grids: all cells on the border cannot have arrows directed outside. It is important because we don't calculate probability of steps to outside. Say, cells in the corners have only two possible steps which has 0.5 probability etc.

Title: RL Course by David Silver - Lecture 3: Planning by Dynamic Programming
Comment: It's called dynamic programming because the Air Force general Bellman was working under was somewhat short sighted and didn't appreciate the value of quantitative research. Thus Bellman chose "Dynamic" for the name of his brand of programming because he felt there was no way to use dynamic in a pejorative sense. Also "...we can think of the value function as caching the solutions to all of our subproblems...." is great stuff. Many thanks.

Title: RL Course by David Silver - Lecture 3: Planning by Dynamic Programming
Comment: The person asking the question at 28:07 is mistaken, and the lecturer's answer is incorrect. The incorrect premise of the question is that the only "terminal state" is the lower right corner, and so the square (3,3) (labelled from the bottom left) should be "further" from the terminal point than (4,3). This is wrong: the top left corner is also part of the terminal state, and is closer to (3,3). Dr. Silver's answer does not address this. Instead, he (apparently incorrectly) says the discrepancy is due to rounding error. However, the numbers shown are consistent with an exact solution of the problem by solving Poisson's equation for the random walk.

Title: Dynamic Programming | Set 4 (Longest Common Subsequence) | GeeksforGeeks
Comment:
*For everyone asking why the matrix is built this way* :
When you are using dynamic programming you need to understand the recursive algorithm you would like to optimize.
I'll explain the non-genius solution where you go letter by letter from the start of each string.
The DP answer will be built bottom-up which would make the table fill from the end of the string as the vid suggests.


In this case (x is L1, y = L2): 
LCS = { 
    1 + LCS(i+1,  j+1) ; IF x[i]==y[j] 
    max(LCS(i+1,  j),  LCS(i,  j+1))  ; ELSE
}
This is the top-down approach.


Now if you would like to convert the recursive solution to a matrix you need to take a bottom-up approach. And so the algorithm will look as follows:
LCS = [N][M] // N = len(x), M = len(y)

if x[i]==y[j]:
    LCS[i][j] = 1 + LCS[i-1][j-1]
else:
    LCS[i][j] = max(LCS[i-1][j], LCS[i][j-1])
Note that the matrix has to have a initialization row and column where all values are 0 in order to have an answer for i-1 and j-1 in the first run.
So if you are coding you should also use the case: 
if (x[i] == 0 || y[j] == 0) -> LCS[i][j] = 0 


You can easily see the correlation between the recursive and the DP solutions.
Just keep practicing, it is a skill worth working for and not black magic (as some may feel after watching this video).

Title: Coin Changing Minimum Coins Dynamic Programming
Comment: people wondering with the formula.. the general rule is that every time u traverse a number keep in mind that that number will carry ahead in this case {7,2,3,6} means Iteration 1 : 7, Iteration 2: {7,2}. He doesn't draw that so looks confusing. Also just sort the array to {2,3,6,7} and then its just knapsack formula min(X[i-1],X[i-nums[j]]+1). no need to traverse in j u can traverse in i. This logic is applicable for subset-sum, partition sum, knapsack, coin change , box stacking.

Title: Principle of Optimality - Dynamic Programming
Comment:
All the comments here saying this proof is "nonsense" - it's not!
It may look weird and confusing the first time you see this kind of proof, so pay attention and try to follow:
Think of it as if we're given AS A FACT that the route named R from origin city 'a' to destination city 'j' is the shortest.
We're not trying to prove that. It's a given fact!
Now what we actually want to prove is that any sub-route inside R (for example from 'a' to some midpoint 'k' that is located between 'a' and 'j') would ALSO be the shortest route to that midpoint.
And why is that?? Because if there would exist a different route from 'a' to 'k' that is shorter, then you could also use it to improve R and reach faster to the final destination 'j'. But that's a contradiction to the GIVEN FACT that we have in the first place (that R is already the shortest).
Thus you prove that any sub-path within a given shortest path, is ALSO a shortest path....

Title: Principle of Optimality - Dynamic Programming
Comment:
I read many comments that the proof doesn't make sense. It does in fact.

The statement to be proved was: R(a.j) is shortest path from a to j         IF             R(a.k) is shortest path from a to k .

And the proof was not to be made about whether R(a.k) is itself the shortest path from a to k or not. This is another subject. He started where we already knew that R(a.k) is the optimal path from a to k.

Title: Cutting Rod dynamic programming
Comment: Hi Tushar. I love your videos as does my entire algorithms class. Just a heads up: the more optimal implementation uses only O(B) space where B is the initial length of the rod. It is the same as for knapsack with repetition. T(b) = max(T(i-1, b-ai) + vi, T(i-1, b)) . You iterate through all the rod lengths for each entry and update the max. So it is still O(nB), but with improved space complexity. Cheers!

Title: Coin Changing Number of ways to get total dynamic programming
Comment:
It's seriously hilarious to see so bad comments for a teacher who explains things like a cakewalk.
Thanks @Tushar Roy. Keep it up.

For those who didn't understand the logic, ponder upon the following things and you will learn.
1. The first column value is one not zero because we can get the denomination without selecting anything.
2. The pattern for solving this question is so intuitive, like if you want to get 4 from only two's then you will get in that number of ways which is equal to getting 2's, because when you get 2's adding a 2 denomination coin will get you 4.
Similarly, if you want to get 6 from two's only, then it is the number of ways getting 4 from two's only.
And as you have calculated for the lower denomination coin, you have to add the lower denomination coin value. That's all.

So, the formula becomes, T[i][j] = T[i-1][j] + T[i][j-val[i]] with handling the other conditions.
Thanks you all.

Comment: Thanks you Tushar Roy for another great video. To all the people asking how to solve such problems, the answer  is simple. Practice 3-4 questions every day and by the time you learn at least 50 dynamic programming problems, you'll be able to solve other problems. At this point every question will seem similar. When you learn one pattern, you will be able to solve some others which uses similar ways to solve. Example: The same approach can be used to solve number to ways to reach a destination or walking up a stair.

Title: Coin Changing Number of ways to get total dynamic programming
Comment:
Good video Tushar - but you skip over a lot of assumptions.

Easy way to understand the mysterious "add 1".  No need of zero column.
Assume "i" represents row (coins) and "j" represents numbers 0->n, n being the target total.
* If coins[i] < j --> copy value from above column
* If coins[i] == j --> Take value from left and add 1 to it.  This is because, when this condition is met, you are adding one more possibility of combinations.
Example: Take case of "coins[i] = j = 3".  
When coins[i] = 3 and j = 2, your value is 2.  You can make "2" as (1, 1 or 2) only.
When coins[i] = 3 and j = 3, you can make "3" as (1,1,1 or 1,2 or 3).
This is true whenever coins[i] = j .
Hope this is helpful :)

Title: Coin Changing Number of ways to get total dynamic programming
Comment:
First row has been talked about below, it's not always just 1 (it was here because any positive integer % 1 = 0)

The number of spaces he goes back is only one, two, three because those are the denominations he used in his example. If the denominations were 2, 3, 5, that's how far you'd look back when he starts adding the cell above and the cell to the left. As he properly stated, you only look back if j >=coins[i], or in other words, if counting backwards coins[i] times doesn't send you off the left end of the matrix. Another way to think about it is if the denomination is larger than the amount of change you're looking to return, that denomination will never occur in a solution set of T[i][j].

Generalize the problem with d denominations in an array D[0..d-1] instead of going straight into concrete numbers, it's way easier.

Title: Programming Interview: 0/1 Knapsack Problem (Dynamic Programming)
Comment: This video doesn't go along with the formula specified. Eg at 19:48, He says B(2,5)= max{B(1,5) , 4+B(2,2)} which is wrong. B(2,5) = max{ B(1,5) , 4 + B(1,2) }. Although the result is the same, it is conceptually wrong to use B(2,2) instead of B(1,2). To go further, 4+B(1,2) means you take item 2 and then check if item 1 can fit in the remaining space for weight after adding item 2. ie 5-3=2 is the remaining weight. So, since you can fit item 1 with weight 2, you add its benefit which is B(1,2)=3. I hope you make necessary changes. Thanks.

Title: Dynamic Programming Introduction
Comment:
This video is wrong for so many reasons:
- The 'run time of Fibonacci' is not defined, because it depends on implementation. You chose to use the recursive solution. That is why your default is O(2^n)
- The run time of the iterative method is O(n), not Omega(n^2), whatever that means 
- You are demonstrating memoization, not dynamic programming
- Your memoization solution is no more 'bottom up' than the default recursive solution (which is 'bottom up' for the same reason - you recurse to your base case and then build up)
- Finally, in reality dynamic programming is just an interview exercise. It is never, ever used by any practicing programmer, just like no practicing programmer has ever had to compute the Fibonacci sequence, write a factorial function, divide without division, or any of the other nonsense we're asked in interviews. But that makes your confident ignorance even more tragic because people seeking to pass interviews will listen to your errant nonsense and fail.

Comment:
This is why we do min(max(...))
The problem statement itself says "minimum number of droppings needed in worst case".
worst case: We take number of trials for 'egg breaking case and not breaking case' then take the maximum among those two for the worst case (obviously worst case is where we do more number of operations(trials here) ).

Title: Egg Dropping Dynamic Programming
Comment:
@Tushar
Solution will always come when you drop first egg from floor/2 floor and when consider the cases.
For example for floor =6, we do 6/2 = 3, we drop from floor 3, there are two possibilities
1)Egg breaks in which case we have 2 floors and 1 egg
2)Egg doesn't break, in which case we have 3 floors and 2 eggs
so, solution will be 1+max(2,2) = 3

So, time complexity will reduce to n*k, rather than n*(k^2)

Please tell if I am missing something.

P.S., I think in case of even no. of floors, we will need to consider both n/2 and ((n/2)+1), but not the rest.

Title: Egg Dropping Dynamic Programming
Comment:
for n floors and 2 eggs , the min number of attempts to find where eggs breaks is n formula being n(n+1)/2 = numberofsteps. For ex : take 10 floors and 2 eggs  -  start with 4 th floor - if it breaks then one could find with the other egg starting with 1st floor in (1 + 3 (1st floor ,then 2nd ...then 4th floor) ) , if it doesn't break try  7th floor , if it breaks then try with second egg from 5th - 7th floor - so number of attempts is 1+1+2( 4th,7th,5th,6th)  ... similar logic for 9th floor and 10th floor ... 
Logic is lets say egg is dropped at different floors x,y,z,,, abs( (0-x) + (x+1-y) + (y+1-z)...) should be equal to n . and they should be consecutive. so n*(n+1)/2 = numberofsteps

else, work with mid to number

Title: Programming Interview: Dynamic Programming: Coin Change Problem
Comment:
There is a Big problem in this solution which leads to the wrong answer
eg. 
Say the coin set is {1,2,5,10} and amount is 3. I think this theory fails in this case.
C(0) = 0, C(1)=1, C(2)=1, C(3) should be 2 {1,2}. But this formula returns 1.
So how i assumed is:
C(3) = MIN {C(3-1), C(3-2), C(3-5)} + 1
       = MIN {C(2), C(1), C(-2)} + 1 [assumed C ( <0 ) = 0 too]
       = MIN {1,1,0} + 1
       = 0 + 1
       = 1
This is wrong cause it will take 2 coins {1,2} to make 3.

this can be resolved if we take c(-Ve)=infinity , which denotes that -Ve value can't be possible .
now lets try the same problem
:
C(3) = MIN {C(3-1), C(3-2), C(3-5)} + 1
       = MIN {C(2), C(1), C(-2)} + 1 [assumed C ( <0 ) = infinity ]
       = MIN {1,1,infinity} + 1
       = 1 + 1
       = 2
now  it will take 2 coins {1,2} to make 3.

Comment:
What if the sum is not possible? your algo will always return 1, but in reality it should 0.

Also another problem with the algo
say {2,3,5} is the coin set and you want to make 4
then C(0) = 0, C(1) = 0, C(2) = 1, C(3) = 1
so C(4) = min {C(4-2), C(4-3)} +1 = min{C(2),C(1)}+1 = min{1,0}+1=0+1=1

but actually you can only make 4 using {2,2} so ans should be 2 not 1
